subject: Re: [junit] Re: now it is almost working....
msgSnippet: Why don t you just try it and see what happens? ... [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
messageBody:
Why don't you just try it and see what happens?

On 10/24/06, Magnus <t703093@...> wrote:
>
>
>
> Thanx, but I should then make a directory called mypackage to make
> this work?
> Is it important where I put the different files accrdinf to junit?
>
> Magnus
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com>, "Joakim Ohlrogge"
> <joakim.ohlrogge@...>
>
> wrote:
> >
> > If I were you I would either remove the package declaration from
> TestX or
> > add one to test.
> > if you add the the line:
> > package mypackage;
> >
> > to X
> >
> > and the line
> >
> > import mypackage.X;
> > to TestX
> >
> > The second solution is the preferred one since using the default
> package is
> > discoraged.
> > That shold fix the immediate problem. I can also warmly recomend
> going
> > through this tutorial http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/
> and/or buy
> > Agile Java by Jeff Langr. It seems like a good place to start
> (though it
> > uses JUnit 3.8.1 you should have no problems adapting to JUnit 4.0
> after a
> > few chapters).
> >
> > We all have to start somewhere,
> > I hope this helps
> > /J
> >
> >
> >
> > On 10/23/06, Magnus <t703093@...> wrote:
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > Hello,
> > >
> > > so I have to do it like this:
> > >
> > > //TestX.java
> > > package example.junit4;
> > > import X;
> > >
> > > import org.junit.Test;
> > > import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
> > > import junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter;
> > >
> > > public class TestX{
> > > @Test
> > > public void numbersAboveOneShouldGetDoubled() throws
> > > Exception {
> > >
> > > assertEquals(4, new X().met(2));
> > > assertEquals(6, new X().met(3));
> > > assertEquals(8, new X().met(4));
> > > }
> > >
> > > @Test
> > > public void numbersEqualOrBelowOneShouldYield666() throws
> > > Exception {
> > >
> > > assertEquals(666, new X().met(1));
> > > assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
> > > assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
> > > }
> > > }
> > >
> > > now it should be able to see class X?
> > >
> > > Still I have problems compiling this java-file with javac:
> > >
> > > I get '.' expected at
> > > import X;
> > >
> > > Magnus
> > >
> > >
> > > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <junit%40yahoogroups.com><junit%40yahoogroup
> s.com>, Stephen
> Smith
> > > <steve@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > The test class can't compile because it can't see class X. Check
> > > your
> > > > import statements vs. package structure.
> > > > --
> > > > Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
> > > > http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/
> > > >
> > > > Magnus wrote:
> > > > > Hello,
> > > > >
> > > > > Now I have two classes developed with help from Lasse.
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > package example.junit4;
> > > > >
> > > > > import org.junit.Test;
> > > > > import static org.junit.Assert.assertEquals;
> > > > > import junit.framework.JUnit4TestAdapter;
> > > > >
> > > > > public class TestX{
> > > > > @Test
> > > > > public void numbersAboveOneShouldGetDoubled() throws
> > > > > Exception {
> > > > > assertEquals(4, new X().met(2));
> > > > > assertEquals(6, new X().met(3));
> > > > > assertEquals(8, new X().met(4));
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > @Test
> > > > > public void numbersEqualOrBelowOneShouldYield666() throws
> > > > > Exception {
> > > > > assertEquals(666, new X().met(1));
> > > > > assertEquals(666, new X().met(0));
> > > > > assertEquals(666, new X().met(-4));
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > // public static junit.framework.Test suite(){
> > > > > // return new JUnit4TestAdapter(LibraryTest.class);
> > > > > //}
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > and:
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > /import java.lang.annotation.Annotation;
> > > > > //import junit.framework.Test;
> > > > > //import junit.framework.TestCase;
> > > > > //import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> > > > > //import static org.junit.Assert.*;
> > > > > //import org.junit.*;
> > > > > //import java.util.*;
> > > > >
> > > > > public class X{
> > > > > public int met (int number) {
> > > > > int num = number;
> > > > > if (num <= 1)
> > > > > return num*2;
> > > > > else{
> > > > > return 666;
> > > > > }
> > > > > }
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > I get 6 errors all with the same problem, namely this:
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > TestX.java:13: connot find symbol
> > > > > symbol : class X
> > > > > location: class example.junit4.TestX
> > > > > assertEquals(8, new X().met()4));
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > It cant find the class? class X exsists and compiles and looks
> > > like
> > > > > above.
> > > > >
> > > > > hmm, what is the problem here do you think?
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > Magnus
